question: But you love me don't you? And nothing will ever change that.
answer: I don't know, just put it back.

question: Oh, gotta go. Here's a little makeout music. Goddamnit, I just can't hit those high notes anymore.
answer: Hi Dad, can I have 100 dollars for a brake job?

question: Did I hear 70 dollars? What do you need 50 dollars for? How's your Mom? Frank, watch the clock.
answer: There's something pathetic parked in front of my house.

question: Come off it, Peggy. And what do you mean your house? This is my house. I paid for it, I'm still paying for it.
answer: I'm still waiting for the mortgage check.

question: I mailed it to you on Wednesday.
answer: Well, today's Saturday and it's still not here.

question: Jesus, Peggy. Take it easy. I'm not used to that stuff. You always did the bills. Blame the damn post office.
answer: That stays.

question: You got a Tab?
answer: I don't buy them anymore. You were the only one who drank them.

question: You don't want them? They're going to make a big comeback any minute. Mark my words, these lamps are going to...
answer: I know. Put Scott through college.

question: I'll think of a way to sell, them. One day.
answer: Are you taking Janet to the reunion tonight?

question: I'm not going. Be right there. I'll go through the rest of this stuff next weekend.
answer: Bye sweetheart.

question: I never thought it would go this far.
answer: If the pastries aren't here by nine thirty, call Monica and threaten her life. I'll be back by noon.

question: Where were you? You said you'd be back at twelve.
answer: This is my old friend Carol.. I told you about her.

question: r was worried about you You didn't even call. You're always on my case if I don't call..
answer: How do you like my hair?

question: I have a lot of unresolved feelings about him. I don't trust him. Besides, I hate those commercials.
answer: I'm sorry I asked. We don't have time for another heartto heart. Here, try on the dress.

question: But I want you and Scott to understand. Do you think he loves Janet? Maybe he's smashed too many fortune cookies.
answer: Come on Mom. Give him a break. He's missing the reunion because of you. You know he wants to go.

question: Then we'd both have a miserable time. What do you think?
answer: Hey, you're a hip chick. You look like you stepped right out of Life magazine. Any time you want to borrow it again, just ask.

question: Borrow?! This was my dress. Maybe it's a mistake. What if I'm the only one? I don't even want to go. Everybody's just going to say... Hi.. Where's Crazy Charlie?
answer: Mom, lots of people are separated and divorced.

question: Not from the guy with the lowest prices in town. I feel ridiculous. Maybe I should go home and change.
answer: Why are you so nervous? What is the matter with you today?

question: Oh, I'm sorry.. Peggy Sue Kelcher, my wife Sharon.
answer: Hello. Nice to meet you. Please call me Peggy. I'm Peggy Bodell now.

question: Where's Charlie? I was in town about a year ago and caught one of his commercials. Really made me laugh.
answer: He's not here. We're getting divorced.

question: Welcome to the singles scene.
answer: I don't know how you do it. I've never even dated anybody but Charlie.

question: You just have to remember... men are like houses and trade upwards... I thought you had a pretty good marriage.
answer: We did for a long time. We just got married too young, and ended up blaming each other for missing out on things.

question: So he started having affairs, and you got depressed. You should have left here years ago, like I did.
answer: It's not the place. I don't buy that. Trapped in the same town forever. The price she would pay for her teenage lust.

question: After you got knocked up, my mother didn't want me to talk to you. She thought it was contagious.
answer: Oh, it's not so bad. I have two wonderful kids, my own business. Still, knowing what I know now, if I had the chance to do it all over again, I'd sure do things a lot differently.

question: Michael Fitzsimmons. I had such a crush on him.
answer: Hi, Peggy. God, that Walter Getz can still dance.

question: Your first boyfriend. What do you think? Any sparks left?
answer: Who knows. Remember... Whatever Walter wants...

question: Sharon Norvik this is Carol Heath, and Maddy Nagle. My oldest and dearest friends. Sharon's married to Richard.
answer: Lucky lady. Hi.

question: The only time people like Dolores used to pay any attention to me was to laugh at me or insult me. That guy, Doug Snell, who shook my hand when we walked in, he used to call me a foureyed worm.
answer: Well, you showed them. You're rich and famous and successful. And you have a beautiful wife.

question: You were always friendly to me. I appreciated that. You know, this used to be a fantasy of mine.
answer: What was?

question: Dancing with you.
answer: You're a sweet man, Richard.

question: I guess part of us never really leaves high school.
answer: You know, I never told anybody this, but I always had a feeling that when you die, before you go to heaven, you get a chance to fly around high school for a while.

question: No. You are the undead. You will live forever if you give me your Twinkie. Come on, let's have it. You hate them anyway.
answer: Young man, stop that.

question: Hey! I just made a deposit in your blood bank. Now I want to make a withdrawal.
answer: I think it's time for your next class -

question: I'm changing banks!
answer: Lie back down and take a deep breath.

question: Lie back down and take a deep breath.
answer: What's going on? Where am I?

question: You passed out for a moment. Nothing to worry about.
answer: How did I get here?

question: Wanna smoke?
answer: No thanks. I gave them up years ago. Where is it?

question: Were taking you back to the nurse.
answer: Maddy, what did you do to your hair?

question: We're going to take you home.
answer: That's okay. I'm sure I'll remember the way.

question: I'll call you Later.
answer: Yes. Let's stay in touch. Peggy. Peggy Sue. Mom!

question: Yes. Let's stay in touch. Peggy. Peggy Sue. Mom!
answer: The nurse called and said you'd be coming home.

question: I have a note.
answer: How do you feel?

question: I'm excused.
answer: Why don't you go lie down for a while.

question: Mom! Chanel Number Five. That always reminds me of home.
answer: Of course, dear. You're home now.

question: I'm home now. Okay, I'm alone now. Is anyone here? No. This is crazy. Is somebody going to tell me what's going on? Why me? What happened? You don't have to show up. I don't have to see you. Just send me a sign. Thanks a lot. 1 guess I'm on my own. Nancy! Come here.
answer: What are you doing?

question: I'm just happy to see you.
answer: Come on! Mom said you were sick. You're never happy to see me.

question: I'm sorry about that. I really want us to be closer. I have enough unresolved relationships in my... life.
answer: Teenagers are weird. And you're the weirdest.

question: Let's do something together.. Do you want to play Monopoly? Or Careers... Clue... Snakes and Ladders?
answer: Okay, what do you want? What dumb favor do you want me to do?

question: It's unbelievable. The man never ages.
answer: Look at Kenny Rossi. Isn't he dreamy? I wish he'd break up with Arlene. She thinks she's so great.

question: Don't eat the red ones.
answer: Why not? They're my favorite.

question: They're bad for you. They cause...red lips. Can't hurt. I'm already dead.
answer: Peggy Sue! Hurry up. Fabian!

question: Peggy Sue! Hurry up. Fabian!
answer: I put your laundry on your beds. Don't forget to put it away.

question: What's for dinner?
answer: Meatloaf.

question: Peggy Sue, what do you think?
answer: Oh, Daddy. You were always doing things like that. That's funny! That's really funny.

question: Young lady, you're drunk!
answer: Just a little. I've had a tough day.

question: I don't see the humor in this. Go to your room immediately. You're grounded.
answer: Grounded? Ha! The story of my life. I don't wanna go to my room. I wanna import Japanese cars. I wanna go to Liverpool and discover the Beatles.

question: I'm still here, aren't I? I may as well enjoy myself. I'm going to go to school today. Dad, I want to apologize for yesterday. The car is a classic. Use it in the best of health.
answer: Thank you.. I accept your apology with the hope that what went on yesterday will never happen again.

question: That would be impossible.
answer: You're so young, this is not the time to start acquiring bad habits.

question: How does Diane like her braces?
answer: Oh yeah. Charlie. How am I going to handle him?

question: What's the matter? Did you two have a fight?.
answer: Sort of.

question: What about?
answer: The house payments.

question: The house payments.
answer: How do you feel?

question: Pretty strange.
answer: Come on. Get in. I can take care of that.

question: Not now, Charlie. I've got a headache. Get used to the word. Roll it around your tongue for a years.
answer: Hey, I can take a hint. You look great today.

question: You drive like a maniac!
answer: I call this the staccato. Not that I'm glad you were sick, but I had a chance to do some thinking last night.

question: Oh yeah?
answer: You know. About what we said on Tuesday. It makes a lot of sense.

question: Refresh my memory.
answer: How could you forget? We talk about seeing other people and you forget?

question: Maybe I blocked it out.
answer: I can understand that.. But please don't start crying again. It's not going to be forever. I figure three years is long enough. I can see it the music pans out. And right after graduation we should start seeing other people. Kind of comparison shop before we settle down and get married. Know what I mean?

question: Why wait?
answer: Well, we got the prom coming up, all these parties. We shouldn't upset our parents?

question: They'll learn to live with it.
answer: You're more shook up than you want to admit. You'll get used to it, we'll still see each other 2, 3 times a week. Want me to drive you home later?

question: Would you?
answer: Would I?!! Why I oughta...

question: Looking good out there.
answer: Thanks.

question: I noticed you were giving me the silent treatment at lunch. I guess I deserved it. I've been thinking about my three year plan and I think it's unworkable. I must have been delirious.
answer: I thought it had a lot of merit.

question: In the abstract maybe. Get a grip on yourself! But when I imagine you going out with other guys, I feel... ah...
answer: Rejected, worthless, miserable.

question: Yeah. Like that.
answer: Good. What a great kite.

question: Good. What a great kite.
answer: I'm writing a book on kite construction. What did you want to talk about?

question: I want to ask you a question. Do you think...time travel is possible?
answer: Are you doing some kind of science project?

question: Sort of.
answer: Well... in a Newtonian framework, the possibilities were limited, but with the advent of relativity theory, the idea of absolute time can no longer be reasonably affirmed. And then, there's Richard's Burrito.

question: What's that?
answer: That's my own theory based on a Mexican food called the burrito. I had it once when my parents took me to Disneyland.

question: I know what a burrito is.
answer: Well, I think time is like a burrito. Sometimes it just folds over on itself and one part touches the other.

question: What's inside?
answer: You can till it with whatever you want. From illusions to memory, from experience to innocence, from happiness to the entire universes

question: So you think time travel is possible? For people?
answer: Absolutely. People, dogs, elephants.

question: Listen, you've gotta keep this a secret. You can't tell a soul. Promise?
answer: Okay. I promise.

question: This is serious. Nobody can know. Ah, I've returned from the future. I traveled back here 25 years.
answer: You probably are crazy. Wait a minute. Is this some kind of joke? I know what you all, think of me. Oh yeah?

question: You have a blind grandfather. One day you're going to invent a machine that reads books for blind people. I read about it. You're going to be famous. You're going to invent a lot of things.
answer: How, did you know about my grandfather?

question: Because I'm telling you the truth. I know what's going to happen. There's going to be test tube babies and heart transplants. And an American named Neil Armstrong is going to walk on the moon. On July 20, 1969.
answer: Holy Toledo! That's six years ahead of schedule! But when did you leave? Are you here until then? Were you there until now? What direction are you going in? Are you a moving point on an infinite line extending into the past? Can anyone do it?

question: I don't know.
answer: I'd be very careful if I were you. You don' t want to fall into the clutches of some madman with plans to manipulate your brain.

question: That's why I was getting a divorce.. What I really think is that I had a heart attack at the reunion and died.
answer: You look pretty good for a corpse.

question: Come on, Richard, I'm serious.
answer: You're giving me the creeps.

question: Am I dead or not?
answer: There's one way to find out.

question: What're you doing?
answer: Confucious says, The way out is through the door. There's a truck. There's your door. Step in front of the truck! If you're dead, it won't matter. The truck'll go right through you. Go ahead! You're dead!

question: No! I don't want to die!
answer: Okay, you're not dead, but according to every law of science what you say happened to you is impossible.

question: What if it's beyond science? What it it's God? I don't know.
answer: You're a molecule in chaos, a discontinuent aberration. Maybe you've just got powers of precognition. Well, maybe you're just out of whack.

question: I told you, I've already lived my life. I don't know how or why I'm here, but you have to help me get back. I want to get back to my real life!
answer: All right, I'll work on it, I'll, do some research. But in the meantime, don't get crazy.

question: I'm trying. I'll see you tomorrow.
answer: What if you're not here tomorrow?

question: This necklace is sapphire, it was my Grandmother's.
answer: Who was that man?

question: It was nobody. Ah... he's a poll, taker. I'm thinking of voting Democrat this year. But don't mention it to your father. How was school today?
answer: It was great to see everybody again. But it's so boring and regimented. Most of what they teach is useless. The worst thing was lunch.

question: Would you get that, dear?
answer: Sure, Mom. Hello.

question: Peggy! What's the matter? Who is it?
answer: It's Grandma. I can't talk to her now. I'm sorry, Grandma.

question: Peggy Sue! What is it? What happened to you?
answer: I had a dream that Grandma died.

question: Well, she is getting on, but she's fine. I told her you weren't feeling well yesterday. She called to find out how you are.
answer: She did? I love her so much, and I haven't seen her in such a long time. And Grandpa Barney. Is he all, right?

question: Yes, he's fine, too. You saw them at Easter.
answer: I'm sorry, Mom. I'll call Grandma back and apologize.

question: That's a good girl... I hate to see you so upset. Tell me, sweetheart. Are you having problems with Charlie? You mentioned something this morning.
answer: I'm confused about a lot of things right now. Charlie's only one of them.

question: Is Charlie pressuring you to do things you don't think you should be doing?
answer: What do you mean?

question: Oh, Beth.
answer: Charlie's downstairs. Why aren't you ready?

question: For what?
answer: Maddy's party.

question: I don't feel very festive.
answer: You accepted an invitation, Maddy's one of your best friends, and I baked the Rice Krispie squares. Enjoy yourself! This is the best time of your life. And the sooner you learn to handle Charlie the better. Get dressed.

question: Of course.
answer: Where did you get that sweater?

question: Great, isn't it?
answer: It's really Fifties. You sort of clash with the world.

question: Hey! What's the fun of being a teenager if you can't dress weird? And we're going to have fun tonight, right?
answer: Right. I promised my mother.

question: Is this slow enough for you?
answer: Charlie, how are you?

question: I'm fine Peggy Sue. And how are you? Are we talking on the phone? Are we pen pals?
answer: Seriously. What's it like to be eighteen?

question: He does?
answer: Carol and I saw you with that creep, Richard, today.

question: First of all, Richard is not a creep. He happens to be an exceptional person. If any of you gave him half a chance, you'd find that out.
answer: God, Peggy, you're so unformed you're practically fetal. You're just taking pity on him 'cause he has no friends.

question: Dolores, can't you be a little kinder to people? You don't even know the boy. If you weren't so neurotic and insecure, maybe you'd shut up for a while and show some compassion.
answer: Are you for real?

question: Charlie, what do you think of Richard Norvik?
answer: Is he gonna help you with that physics stuff?

question: He's trying.
answer: Hey! Who needs physics when we've got chemistry?

question: Mmm. This is nice. I always loved the way you kiss. I missed you.
answer: Your eyes look like silver pools of moonlight. And the tide rushes in.

question: You really love me, don't you?
answer: You know I do. I even wrote you into my will.

question: Charlie, let's make love.
answer: What?! You mean sex?! Intercourse? You want to have intercourse! Last weekend you said... What time is it?

question: A lot's happened since last weekend.
answer: But you're the one who wanted to wait till we got married. And you were right. We should wait.

question: I probably meant it when I said it. Doesn't Lucky Chuckie want to come out?
answer: Who?

question: You know. Your love machine... the throbbing thrill hammer... your thing!
answer: You mean my wang? Listen, it's running real late. What is this? What the hell is going on? One week you say, "If you love me you won't", now you say "If you love me you will". Excuse me. That's a guy's line!

question: This is a mistake. We better forget it.
answer: You're damn right! Jesus! Peggy! You sure know how to spoil a mood.

question: I'm sorry Charlie.
answer: Save it.

question: Monica? Aren't you Monica Hines? Ah... never mind. Can I have a coffee, please? And a cinnamon cruller. How's Bobo? You're kidding? I was impressed with what you said in English class today.
answer: Gilfond's okay, except he thinks Hemingway's great Literature.

question: You don't?
answer: He's a fisherman! The most overrated writer of the century. I mean, he's the perfect American author  fat, violent, drunk...

question: Maybe you're confusing his life with his work.
answer: A writer's life is his work. Jack Kerouac doesn't have to kill a bull to have something to write about. He's out there feeling, burning... grooving on life!

question: The young man leaned back in his chair. No bulls would die today.
answer: What're you doing here anyway?

question: Coffee and a donut.
answer: I thought chicks like you traveled in packs.

question: Terry, slow down.
answer: Okay.

question: Terry! Slow down.
answer: What, why?

question: There's Peggy with Michael Fitzsimmons.
answer: That commie beatnik? What's she doing with him? Wait'll I tell Charlie.

question: This is great reefer.
answer: Yeah. I'm surprised. It's really old... Travels well though. You know, the world looks a lot better from up here.

question: The world is fantastic. It's the ultimate absurd circus. I am shot from a cannon into the energy.
answer: What are you shooting for?

question: Maximum intensity. Yeah. I can't wait to get out of here. I'm gonna write. I'm gonna check out of this bourgeois motel. Push myself away from the dinner table and say 'No more JellO for me, Mom.'
answer: Don't you get along with your parents?

question: The only thing my father digs is cold, green money. All my mother cares about is her standing at the country club.
answer: They care about you. They're just a different generation.

question: Hey what's with you? I thought you were cool. You rode my bike. You blew some pot. What's your scene Miss Majorette? You gonna marry Mr. Blue Impala and graze around with all the other sheep for the rest of your life?
answer: I already did that. I want to be a dancer, I want to dance.

question: You know, I had you pegged all wrong. A ray of oneness piercing the solitude. Falling bodies in the ecstasy of flesh. You'll be a chapter in my memoirs of desire.
answer: Is that one of your poems?

question: No, I just made that up. Do you want to hear one?
answer: I'd love to.

question: Okay. Here's a new one. It's called Tenderness. I couldn't sleep so I thought I'd scream Betrayed by a kiss, sucking pods of bitterness. In the madhouse of Dr. Dread Razor shreds of rat puke fall On my bare arms I'm sorry. I guess I was trying to impress you.
answer: Michael... you're as good as you looked.

question: I'll respect you for eternity. 'When you are old and gray, and full of sleep, And nodding by the fire, Take down this book, and slowly read, And dream of the soft look your eyes had once." I didn't write that. That's Yeats.
answer: I envy you. You have your whole life ahead of you and you know exactly what you want to do. But forget the rat puke; write something beautiful. You know, this isn't really happening. Thanks, Ralph.

question: I went for a drive. Up in the hills.
answer: Damn that Charlie I

question: It's not Charlie. It's me.
answer: Peggy, let me ask you something. You're not... expecting are you?

question: At my age? Don't be silly.
answer: Thank God for that.

question: Dad.. it's not a big deal. Didn't you ever stay out all night when you were young?
answer: Yes but I was a boy. And I still had hell to pay.

question: Calm down. Just listen for a minute.. Please.
answer: All right. But this better be good.

question: I want to help with the family finances. I want you to buy some stocks. And gold. By 1980 gold is going to be worth eight hundred dollars an ounce. Then you sell.
answer: Do you know how ridiculous you sound? First of all, it's illegal for U.S. citizens to buy gold. And in the second place, the price of gold is regulated by the government.

question: I think they're going to deregulate it.
answer: That's your problems The more women think, the more trouble they get into.

question: Oh boy, that's another thing that's going to change. Who's going to think for us? Our husbands? You know, you treat Mom like a maid. It's not entirely your fault. Those were the attitudes in the fifties, and that's the way you raised me. But give Nancy a break, encourage her to go to art school.
answer: I've heard just about enough of this lunacy! Go to your room!

question: Listen Dad, please. Buy IBM, buy Polaroid, buy Apple Computer. No, no. Not yet. Buy Xerox!
answer: Evelyn, take her to her room!

question: Way to go, Mom!
answer: The way I see it, you have an unparalleled opportunity to become the richest woman in the world.

question: I'm just not the type. Besides, I want to get out of here.
answer: But you have a vision. Don't you want to help your parents?

question: I tried to tell them, but they wouldn't listen to me.
answer: I'm talking about invention, no investment. I know what people think of me. Mr. Spasmatician. Dick the Square Root. I'll show them. You said I was going to be a millionaire. And you're gonna help!

question: Richard, take it easy.
answer: No offense, but for a person who says she's lived an extra lifetime, you certainly are thick. Money is power.. Money makes people respect you...

question: How come you never ask me any important questions? Don't you wonder if there's going to be a nuclear war? Or a cure for cancer? What about your family? What about people?
answer: I'm curious, but I don't want to know. Jeez, I hope you haven't been telling people what's going to happen to them.

question: Give me some credit, will you?
answer: Good. You're discreet. I like that in a partner.

question: Wbat're you talking about?
answer: Look it's very simple. You tell me everything that hasn't been invented yet, and I'll invent it. We'll be partners. Fiftyfifty.

question: Sixtyforty. Okay, find yourself another vision.
answer: You're taking advantage of a minor.

question: When do we start?
answer: A Ton on a Bun, with fries.

question: Quiche Lorraine, spinach salad and a Perrier. Dry cleaners. No real change. Just higher prices. Ah. This is a biggie. Forget sneakers. Running shoes, jogging shoes, tennis shoes. Fifty to two hundred dollars a pair.
answer: Come on. You can't be serious.

question: There are major fortunes to be made here. Leisure time and lifestyles.
answer: Are you talking ~about exercise? Like gym?

question: Not for you. Okay, there's lots more. Look at that stuff. It's like the dark ages. This is more your speed. And boy, do I know this business.
answer: Let's see... icrowavemays, ocketpay alculatorcays...

question: You don't have to use pig Latin! Nobody could possibly know what we're talking about.
answer: All right. These are the choices

question: Oh. And huge portable radios. Everything else gets small, but for some reason, portable radios get enormous. I'll be right back. Richard! They don't have any! They never heard of them! Isn't that wonderful?
answer: What are you talking about?

question: The wave of the future! I've decided on our first fortune! I'll see you later. You just think high tech.
answer: High tech. I like the sound of that.

question: Woody! How ya doing? Nice to see you.
answer: Take the Shostakovich home and listen to it. Let it grow on you. Everyone that's bought it has come back and said, "This is definitive Shostakovich. Thank you for encouraging me to investigate it." You'll like it. I kid you not.

question: What do you know about classical music?
answer: Nothing.. Selling is selling.

question: Charlie. About last nights..
answer: Forget it. I've been thinking. Girls must go through that stuff too. Sometimes when I look at you I feel like an animal. Maybe my dad's right. Teenagers are nuts.

question: But I'm not. I'm a grown woman with a lifetime of emotional experiences you couldn't possibly understand.
answer: Yeah, I know. Girls mature faster than guys. But last night, I was the one who put on the brakes. And you know why?

question: Why?
answer: Because nothing else matters. That's the great thing about love. Every time we argue, every time something goes wrong, and I know that I'm not perfect either, things just work out better in the end. Cause you're my baby and I love you.

question: What am I going to do with you?
answer: Don't be cruel to a heart that's true.

question: Hi, Dad.
answer: Doing some shopping? For me?

question: Open it.
answer: Sweetheart, they're beautiful. But they must've been expensive.

question: I closed my Christmas club.
answer: Good, you got your money out of that greedy bank.

question: I wanted to apologize for this morning.
answer: It's hard to believe you're going to be eighteen. Want an eskimo pie? Or a creamsicle? I'd come home from the store and there's little you running up to me. I'd give you a dime and you'd promise never to grow up.

question: Quiet today?
answer: This morning was good.

question: The hat business is in trouble.
answer: I, that what all that nonsense was about this morning? You're worried about my business?

question: Yes.
answer: That's very thoughtful, honey. It's just a slump. Things will pick up.

question: But when John F. Kennedy's elected President, men'1l stop wearing hats.
answer: Kennedy's a Catholic. He'll never win.

question: He'll win.
answer: Richard Nixon's going to be President. Nixon wears hats.

question: I don't need your charity. I don't need your grandmother's jewelry or your parents money -how could you do that?
answer: Please don't shout.

question: I'm not shouting. Have we ever starved? Have we ever missed a mea1?
answer: Does everybody have to hear?

question: I want everybody to hear because I don't have anything to be ashamed of.
answer: Jack, I was just trying to help.

question: ) Oh, Maddy, grow up. It says in LOVE WITHOUT FEAR that "the tongue kiss as a means of genital stimulation is widely practiced and has much to commend it". Page eightysix.
answer: Did you memorize the whole book or only the good parts?

question: Just what you underlined.
answer: You're kidding...? Carol, you have beautiful hair.

question: Wrong, Dad. Your idea. Charlie. I just had the strangest dream.
answer: I have to talk to you..

question: What are you doing here?
answer: Let's go down to the basement. I want to know what's going on. Dolores told me that you and that scuzzball Michael Fitzsimmons...

question: I bumped into him after you dropped me off Last night. I didn't feel like going home, so we went for a ride.
answer: Then it's true, dammit! I had a miserable time tonight 'cause of you. When the Monotones did "Book of Love  Chapter Four you break up, won't you give it just one more chance..." I'm thinking Did we break up? 'Cause if we did, I don't even know about it!. I thought we cleared all that up yesterday. Did that Maynard G. Beatnik give you what you wanted?

question: You know I never could stand your sarcasm.
answer: You're going to blow it, Peggy Sue. Nobody treats Charlie Bodell like this.

question: And why do you always refer to yourself in the third person, like Napoleon? How come it always turns into an argument with you?
answer: Look, I've got the hair, got the eyes, got the teeth, I got the car. I'm the lead singer, I'm the man.

question: Charlie,. I've been trying to postpone this. But what's the point? It's over. I don't want to hurt you. This is very hard for me. I'm doing this for both of us. I really want you to be happy.
answer: I will be happy if I have you. I love you.

question: That won't make any difference. We just can't live together. And you had the nerve to drive up with that bimbo Janet.
answer: What are you talking about? Who's Janet?

question: I just can't trust you anymore.
answer: What about everything I said to you this afternoon...

question: That's just it. You can always get to me. There's this window in my heart and every time I leave it open, you climb in. Unless I close it now, nothing's ever going to be different!
answer: But what has to be different?

question: Everything. I have a good head for business, I should be franchising the bakery. And I want you to give me your word that whatever happens, you'll go to college. And finish.
answer: What! What about the group and my singing career? What about me?

question: I'm trying to save you years of frustration... waiting for a big break... no. Waiting for that big disappointment so you could blame it all on me.
answer: You don't know zip! You think I'm going to end up selling appliances like my father? Chasing women around the store. I've got to give it a shot. Why are you trying to kill the two things that mean the most to me? Until yesterday you loved me and you loved us. ) What the hell has changed? For two years I've done nothing but love you. I'll show you, I'm going to be just like Fabian!

question: Hello, Grandma. It's Peggy Sue. Much better. How are you? I'm very sorry about the other day. Hi, Richard.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Jogging. I was running, now I'm jogging.
answer: That's what you were talking about yesterday? Everybody does that in the future?

question: Yep. It's going to be a law. I broke up with Charlie last night.
answer: That's terrific. You did it. You really changed the course of your destiny.

question: It was an unfair fight. He didn't have a chance. I'm taking a real gamble. I loved him for a long, long time.
answer: Cheer up. Now you can give some other guy a shot. Make it up to him later and buy him a yacht.

question: For God's sake, forget the money! I'm going crazy! I'm a walking anachronism. I'm a puddle of deja I'm worried about my kids, Scott must be scared to death, I think my daughter's doing drugs again. I can't have any fun here, I don't have that innocence any more. I can't keep all this in anymore. I feel Like I'm going to explode.
answer: Look, the best scientific mind in this country is working on your case. May I make a suggestion?

question: Like what?
answer: Suggestion! Hypnotic suggestion! Why didn't I think o~ that before?

question: What do you know about hypnosis?
answer: Everything. This is perfect. The subconscious mind remembers all. You can give me more information on microchips and then pinpoint what happened at the reunion. Maybe that'll give us a clue on how to get you back.

question: Look, I'm desperate. I'll try anything. But what if you can't snap me out of it?
answer: No offense, but you're pretty out of it now. You are completely relaxed. When I count to three, you will open your eyes. One... two... three. We'll start with something easy. What is your name?

question: Peggy Sue Kelcher. Or, Peggy Bodell. I'm not sure.
answer: Oh boy. Peggy, what are microchips?

question: Ah..... they're very tiny... they look like a fingernail made out of an erector set...
answer: What will they be made of?

question: I think it's called silicon. Charlie told me that.
answer: Silicon is from sand.

question: We were lying in the sand. It was my eighteenth birthday... We were so awkward... I would have married him anyway...
answer: In the future, will you have to marry a girl before you have sex with her?

question: No. The Pill will change all that. Then he wouldn't have blamed me. We were just too young.
answer: You mean you'll give a girl a pill and she'll want to have sex?

question: No. The Pill will be for birth control. But girls do like sex. Maybe not the first time.
answer: Will you take of f your blouse?

question: Yes, every day. Maybe I shouldn't have worn that dress? I told Beth it was a bad idea. That's why they made me Queen.
answer: No! Yes! I'll be right out, Dad. Oh shit! Peggy, I'm going to snap you out of it.

question: I couldn't help it  I loved him.
answer: One... two... three. You are now awake.

question: Richard! You should be ashamed of yourself.
answer: Me? You went crazy! You started taking your clothes off. I was putting them back on for you.

question: That's just perfect isn't it? Did it work? Did you find out why I came back?
answer: I think it has something to do with your birthday. You were rambling. I didn't understand the rest.

question: God dammit! How'm I gonna got out of here?
answer: Hey! Do you have any idea how much those beakers cost? I usually charge for hypnosis.

question: Oh, go feel up your hamsters! I hear rodents put out.
answer: You know, dear, I think the pantyhose is a wonderful idea, but the next time you come up with something, please don't stay out all night. Just tell us. We'll believe you.

question: Mom, how about a machine that's like your blender, only it slices vegetables, kneads dough, chops meat and even make fresh pasta?
answer: These roses are beautiful. And so romantic'. Who is this Michael? Is he a friend of Charlie's?

question: No, just a friend of mine. I don't think he Likes JellO.
answer: What does Charlie think about that?

question: You know Mom, it's okay to have male friends. Besides, it's over with me and Charlie.
answer: What? When did it happen? Your dad and I always expected you two to get married.

question: Yeah, I know Peggy Sue gets married. Case closed. Period. Mom, if you could live your life over again, would you do the same thing? Get married and settle down after high school? Why?
answer: All the college girls I knew were so well, dressed. I was worried that I wouldn't fit in. I didn't have the right clothes. I was so silly. But, I don't have many regrets, and besides, r don't have time to worry about the past. But Charlie. I hope you know what you're doing.

question: That was quite an evening. Bourgeois, phony, decadent, stupid.
answer: I shouldn't have put you through that. It must have been agony. Let's do something. No. Something else. I'm too full. Besides, it's a school night.

question: Five more weeks of school. And ten minutes past graduation I'm gone. To freedom.
answer: For everyone.

question: Now listen, this is the plan. As soon as school is finished we go to Utah and...
answer: Utah? I thought you'd be going to New York or Paris. What's in Utah?

question: Rita. I met her last summer. She's cool. You'll really dig her. She's got this great little cabin in the hills, just outside of Provo where she raises chickens. I'll write and the two of you can take care of the chickens to support us.
answer: I can't do that.

question: Why not? Polygamy's legal in Utah.
answer: I hate chickens.

question: But what about the other night? We were like two stars in the same constellation.
answer: Michael, you and I are light years apart. You should go, but not with me.

question: But we had heat baby. Passion! Fire! We owe it to ourselves to fuse together. At least one more time.
answer: That's a terrific line. You're going to be a wonderful writer.

question: You think so?
answer: Yes. We had a glorious night together. One day you'll remember and write about it.

question: I can dig that. Bittersweet perfection. Dogs of lust on leashes of memory... yeah. Now I get it.
answer: Ssh. He's great.

question: Peggy Sue's still stuck on treble without a cause.
answer: I thought I knew everything about him.

question: Can we split now? I can dig you being uptight about Rita and Utah. That's cool. But I've got to warn you about something.
answer: What?

question: My father. He's not just the ultimate square. He's a total crook.
answer: How did it go with the pantyhose?

question: What're you doing here?
answer: I wanted to talk to you, and I have one last thing to take care of at school. Then I'm going to... Good dog, Rusty. Good dog.

question: Rusty's dead. That's Ajax
answer: Oh. I guess I always liked Rusty better. Could you give me a ride to school?

question: Sorry, the Blue Thunder's out of commission for a while.
answer: Well, how about a walk, Charlie Bell..

question: How'd you know about that?
answer: I was at Lena's last night. You were terrific.

question: Not terrific enough. What were you doing in that part of town? Who were you with?
answer: What were You doing there? You never told me you were singing with an R and B group.

question: Hey. I guess there's a lot of things we don't know about each other.
answer: I'd forgotten how much music meant to you.

question: That's real big of you.
answer: Stop being defensive. I want to help you. I wrote a song for you.

question: You're kidding. You wrote a song? Is it about a guilty girl and a trusting guy... she wants to hurt him, and he wonders why?
answer: Not exactly, but with your great voice, it'll be a huge hit. Honest.

question: Fat chance. You know, Lee Wilkins came to hear me last night. He told me to forget it. You told me to forget it. My parents tell me to forget it.
answer: Just take a look at it.

question: If you took the trouble to write it, then sure, I'll take a look at it. But I'm beginning to think that maybe there's more to life than music. I wonder if people would still like me if I stopped being Mr. Excitement? Does this mean you like me again?
answer: It means I care about you and what happens to you.

question: Peggy, I have to talk to you.
answer: What's the matter?

question: It's that jerk Walter.
answer: What happened?

question: After Charlie told Walter that he broke up with you because he wanted to play the field, Walter decided he should do the same thing.
answer: Welcome to the singles' scene.

question: What a I going to do for the rest of my life? I don't have a boyfriend anymore.
answer: Look, Carol, maybe Walter's done you a big favor. You always said you wanted to get out of town. Go for it. And be happy, goddamnit, I'm rooting for you.

question: What's the matter, princess? Lost your prince?
answer: You know Dolores, there's a lot of things I could say to you, but you're not worth the effort. Sorry. These fountain pens are so tricky.

question: Oh! You did that on purpose! I hate you. Go gargle with razor blades!
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: Take a long walk on a short pier.
answer: Have a nice day. Rosalie! Wait!

question: Have a nice day. Rosalie! Wait!
answer: What's up?

question: I think you should give up diving. It's dangerous.
answer: Don't be silly, I'm the best in the county.

question: I know you are, but you have to stop. I couldn't tell you before, I didn't know if I should. But you have to stop before you hurt yourself.
answer: I spend three hours a day practicing. I have trainers, I know what I'm doing.

question: But accidents can happen.
answer: Not to me they don't. I'm going to win the State, then the. Nationals, and then I'm going to the Olympics.

question: Rosalie, please, listen to me! You have to stop.
answer: You're sick. You should go to the nurse. I'm going to tell Miss Dennis.

question: What's the matter?
answer: It's all, gone wrong, nothing's working out.

question: Not true. I think I'm making real progress on the microchip.
answer: You were meant to. You're one of those fortunate people that good things happen to. I have to get out of here.

question: Peggy, I believe you. I believe everything you told me. It's wonderful. You're the exception that proves the rule.
answer: I love you too, Richard. Thanks for trying.

question: I love you too, Richard. Thanks for trying.
answer: Hey, Peggy. Wait a minute. I cut shop and did some work on your song. You know, it's not half bad for your first try. Of course, I changed all the "yeahs" to "oohs". Listen to this.

question: Forget it, it'll never work.
answer: Okay. Listen, I cancelled the tickets for Fabian. I thought it would be better for your birthday to eat at a nice restaurant, Chez Tres.

question: I remember that book! Grandpa, Grandma, I want to tell you something.
answer: If you believe it, darling, then I believe. Being young can be just as confusing as being old. The things that happened to me fifty years ago are more on my mind than what happened yesterday.

question: But I'm remembering the future.
answer: Right now you're just browsing through time. Choose the things you'll be proud of. The things that Last.

question: My children make me happy. I miss them so much. Beth. Scott and Beth. I'm going to name my daughter after you.
answer: It's gonna rain again. Every time I wash the car, it rains.

question: That never changes. You know, when you and Grandma are gone, the family's gone. I never see the cousins anymore.
answer: It's your grandma's strudel that's kept this family together.

question: Grandpa, if you had a chance to do it all again, what would you do?
answer: I'd take better care of my teeth.

question: What does Grandma think you do at your meetings?
answer: Stag movies. Smokers. I may be an old fool, but I think we can help you.

question: I hope so. At least I got to see you and Grandma. Has it ever worked before?
answer: The last one was six hundred years ago. It's about time for another one.

question: Thank you. Ah... thank you.
answer: Let me take your jacket, Lilla. I've got, to get my robe.

question: Do you have to wear that hat?
answer: It wouldn't be a lodge without hats. Don't you worry. I'll be watching after you.

question: Yes, sir. Fasten your seat belts. Here we go. This is never going to work. What the hell did you do that for? What are you doing here?
answer: I was trying to save you. They were going to vaporize you.

question: Don't be ridiculous! They're just a bunch of harmless old men. My grandfather was in there.
answer: You're going to listen to me.

question: I'm not getting in that blue monstrosity. Let me got! Where are you taking me?
answer: Right here. Now sit down. Look. I wanna tell you. I forgive you for everything. I know what you've been going through. You're just scared. I was scared, too, but I'm not anymore.

question: How could you possibly know what I've been going through?
answer: Because I love you, damnit! I had a long talk with your father yesterday and we decided that the best thing for us to do is get married and settle down. Right away.

question: What do you mean you and my father decided? Who the hell are you to plan my life? Let's get married and live happily ever after. Bullshit. I got knocked up. I had to marry you. I never had a choice.
answer: What?

question: You betrayed me, Charlie. You were never there for me or the children. And now you come and tell me, "Peggy, you're scared." Of course I'm scared. If you knew what I knew you'd be scared shitless.
answer: You're crazy! You're really out of your mind!

question: I might be crazy, but I'm not crazy enough to marry you twice. There's a lot of things I can't change. I can't even think about them. I tried. But I couldn't even help Rosalie. I don't want to be bitter. I'm a naturally optimistic person. But you took advantage of that.
answer: Oh, Peggy. My poor Peggy. It's all my fault. I'm so sorry. I won't bother you anymore. I promise. Please stop crying. Please.

question: Will you take me back to my grandparents?
answer: Of course. It's almost your birthday. I wasn't sure when you were coming back, so I brought your present up here.

question: Oh, Charlie.
answer: It opens, too. Look inside.

question: Scott and Beth. Where did you get these? So are Scott and Beth.
answer: I love you.

question: I know.
answer: I think we should get out of here. It's going to rain.

question: Do you think anybody in the Fifties ever made love on a bed?
answer: What the hell is that? Peggy! Where're you going? Come back!

question: I've got to go now.
answer: But I love you. I'll love you forever.

question: I'll love you, too, Charlie. I'll love you for twenty years.
answer: Come back to me.

question: I'm trying.
answer: Richard, do something!

question: Peggy! . Peggy Sue, I love you, and I need you Peggy Sue...
answer: Charlie? Was I dead?

question: I thought you were...for a while.
answer: You look awful, like you haven't slept in days. And so old.

question: But happy. Very happy, Peggy Sue.
answer: Charlie, I thought I knew everything about you.

question: I wanted to apologize. I can't live without you.
answer: What about Janet?

question: That's over. I got tired of translating everything. She thought the Big Hopper was a hamburger.
answer: Who are all the flowers from?

question: Everyone. Maddie and Arthur, Carol and Walter. Richard Norvick. And here's a book, by that guy from high school, Michael Fitzsimmons. He dedicated it to you.
answer: It couldn't be me. I hardly knew him.

question: I'll just set it right here.
answer: Charlie, I had a strange experience. I went back to high school. And I spent a lot of time with you. And you and Walter and Leon were singing "I Wonder Why".

question: Oh, God, Dion.
answer: You were terrific. And I kept trying to push you away but you wouldn't give up.

question: I'll never give up.
answer: Then hold me.

question: I loved you since the day I met you, and I haven't stopped.
answer: Don't try to charm me, Charlie Bodell.

question: Listen, I don't expect all the troubles between us can just vanish away. But I would do what I can... Well, I'll let you get some rest...so long.
answer: Charlie, I would like to invite you to dinner at home, on Sunday, with your kids. I will make a strudel.
